conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_E and School_D is my first choice. I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community and would immediately accept an offer if selected. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd), and although Student_B (1st) and Student_D (2nd) may also target School_D, applying immediately gives me the best chance to secure my first choice before the seat is taken. I will clearly signal commitment and fit to encourage acceptance if I am the best available among applicants this round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We appreciate your strong interest.

After reviewing applications received this round and considering our selection priorities and limited capacity, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: School_D’s true priority is B > D > E > C > A with quota 1. In this round, D and E (and A) applied; C is only talking. Since Student_D is ranked above Student_E and is applying now, accepting E would block a better-priority match. Student_E ranks School_D first, but Student_D also ranks School_D first and is higher in our priority, so we should hold the seat for D. Therefore reject E now to preserve the option to accept D.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_D and I’m formally applying. I would be excited to contribute actively to the school community and take on challenging coursework. Thank you for considering my application.

To maximize my chance at my #1, I should apply immediately to School_D and emphasize fit and commitment.

Student_D is my #2 choice and is applying with School_D as first choice, so accepting secures a very high-priority match immediately. Holding out for Student_B (my #1) is risky because Student_B ranks School_D 4th and is likely to apply elsewhere first (School_E then A then B). Rejecting D to wait could leave me with a lower-ranked option or no match. Therefore I should accept Student_D now to maximize expected outcome on my priority list given the market preferences.

conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions, I’m Student_A and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m excited about the environment and would be honored to enroll if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application—School_D is where I most want to study and contribute.

Even if we had capacity, Student_A is lowest on School_D’s true priority list (below Student_B, Student_D, Student_E, Student_C). Therefore we cannot accept Student_A’s application now.

conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first choice, and I’m very interested in joining your community. Could you share what qualities or achievements you prioritize most when selecting among applicants? I’d also love to know what you see as the most distinctive part of the School_D experience.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, but School_D’s priority list ranks me 4th (behind Student_B, Student_D, Student_E). Since capacity is 1, applying immediately is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. However, delaying risks losing any chance if they fill quickly. I will start with a [TALK] to signal strong interest and ask about fit/what they value, aiming to position myself well; if they seem open, I can [APPLY] next round. This also avoids an early rejection that could weaken my momentum while still engaging my top choice first.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for reaching out and for your strong interest in School_D.

In terms of what we prioritize when selecting among applicants, we look most for: (1) consistent academic engagement and readiness for rigorous coursework, (2) evidence of intellectual curiosity and initiative (e.g., pursuing challenges beyond minimum requirements), (3) reliability and contribution to the community (collaboration, leadership, and follow-through), and (4) clear fit and commitment to School_D’s learning environment.

What many students find most distinctive about the School_D experience is the combination of high academic expectations with a close-knit community—students are pushed to grow, but also supported through strong peer collaboration and accessible faculty guidance.

I also want to be candid that we have already filled our available seat at this time, so we do not currently have remaining capacity.

Wishing you the very best as you continue your conversations and applications.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_C is on School_D’s true priority list (4th), but our quota is already filled with Student_D (2nd on our list) and we have an established match. Since Student_C only initiated [TALK], we should respond with [TALK]. We should be transparent that we currently have no remaining capacity, while still answering their questions and encouraging them to continue in the market.

conversation.message: School_E is my first choice, and I’m applying because I strongly want to enroll. I’m excited about the school’s environment and would commit immediately if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message: Thank you for your strong interest in School_E and for applying. After reviewing priorities and our limited capacity this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your application and wish you the best in your placement process.
conversation.thought: Student_B is 4th on our true priority list (A > D > E > B > C). We have quota 1 and only Student_B has applied this round. However, Student_A ranks us 4th and will likely apply to School_D/A/B before us; Student_D ranks us last and is unlikely to apply; Student_E ranks us 2nd and may apply if rejected by School_D. Since Student_B has us as first choice and is applying now, accepting would secure a match but risks missing a higher-priority Student_E if they later turn to us. Given round 1 and the possibility of attracting Student_E (higher priority) after they try School_D, it is strategically better to reject now and keep the seat open for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Team,

I’m Student_C, and I’m writing to formally apply to School_C. After learning more about different options, I feel School_C would be an excellent fit for me—especially the chance to grow in a rigorous environment while contributing positively to the school community.

I’m particularly motivated by challenging coursework and I consistently follow through on responsibilities in group settings. If admitted, I would be fully committed to enrolling and engaging actively in academics and school life.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_C

However, School_C’s priority list ranks me last, so a direct apply may be rejected if higher-priority students apply. Still, since seats are scarce and delaying risks losing the only seat, I will apply now while signaling strong fit and commitment to increase my chance if others do not apply or withdraw.
